image.altText: A woman sits on a bench looking at an iPad

props.synopsis: Hundreds of thousands of Australians slugged more than $60 million in excessive bank fees could soon get a refund, but Commonwealth Bank customers may not see a cent of $270 million in unfair charges.

title.children: Commbank refuses to pay millions in refunds to low-income customers

image.altText: A light-coloured single-storey building with green lawn, a driveway and metal gates in front.

props.synopsis: A Queensland childcare worker has been charged with torturing and repeatedly assaulting a one-year-old baby boy.

title.children: Educator charged with torturing baby boy in childcare centre

image.altText: A close-up of Jim Chalmers in front of a grey background

props.synopsis: There's a great deal riding on the contentious proposal, politically for the Albanese government, personally for Treasurer Jim Chalmers and economically for the nation.

title.children: Gas shortage crisis develops as Santos takeover heats up

image.altText: Donald Trump sits in front of a US flag.

props.synopsis: Donald Trump suggests the US's 10 per cent "baseline" tariff, which is placed on most of Australia's exports to the US, could soon increase to 15 or 20 per cent.

title.children: Trump suggests 10pc tariff imposed on Australia could double

image.altText: An older man in a suit and red, spotted tie, speaks into a microphone on a podium during an address.

props.synopsis: Australia will not change its position on US trade barriers despite US President Donald Trump threatening to double the baseline tariff. Follow live.

title.children: Australia responds to Trump's latest tariff threat

liveBlogKeyEvents.title: Australia trying to get 'sense' of what Trump administration planning
Australia position on tariffs 'unchanged' following fresh Trump threat
Donald Trump flags plan for 15-20pc tariff 'for the world'

image.altText: Children holding empty bowls pushing in a crowd to get food.

props.synopsis: For the first time, the two leading human rights organisations have called for the international community to put pressure on the Netanyahu government to change course in the Palestinian territory.

title.children: Israeli human rights groups say their country is committing genocide in Gaza

image.altText: Donald Trump

props.synopsis: US President Donald Trump says he will give Russia 10 to 12 days to agree to a ceasefire with Ukraine, slashing the 50-day deadline he initially floated.

title.children: Trump tells Putin he has '10 to 12' days to end Russia-Ukraine war

image.altText: An ASX board with ASX in focus and stock prices out of focus.

props.synopsis: Unions want AI job protections and Australian job data is set to come out ahead of tomorrow's keenly anticipated inflation read. Follow the events and insights from our business reporters on the ABC News live markets blog.

title.children: European markets roar on EU-US trade deal

image.altText: A man silhouetted against a window.

props.synopsis: The ABC's Foreign Correspondent travels to cartel country in Mexico to see if the government's crackdown on drug cartels is working.

title.children: 'Right now, things is crazy': Why a Sinaloa cartel-linked smuggler is feeling the heat

image.altText: An orange ute with bonnet up and doors open, in a showroom.

props.synopsis: Electric vehicles are accelerating in the Australian market, but there are concerns over charging access, affordability and looming tax changes that could stall progress.

title.children: 'Cheaper' electric vehicles flood Australia but face roadblocks

image.altText: A lage building surrounded by snow

props.synopsis: Experts warn Russia and China's plans to expand their presence in Antarctica may be linked to mining or military ambitions in the designated nature reserve.

title.children: Russian and Chinese plans for Antarctic expansion spark alarm

image.altText: A person holds a phone in from of a laptop, with a green line graph showing a share price going up over time.

props.synopsis: Global financial markets are entering an optimistic but potentially dangerous speculative phase, according to analysts, driven by a mania for so-called meme stocks made popular on social media.

title.children: Analysts say 'greed is good' is back as market euphoria surges

image.altText: Kaylee McKeown on the wall after a race at the World Aquatics Championships.

props.synopsis: Five-time Olympic gold medallist Kaylee McKeown sets up a showdown with rival Regan Smith, while Australian teammate Alex Perkins climbs the podium in Singapore.

title.children: McKeown unfazed if she comes last at world titles

image.altText: A portrait of a young woman with black hair sitting in a park.

props.synopsis: 16-year-old Jasmine Flowers was left with life-altering injuries after falling from an e-scooter. She wants riders to understand the risks.

title.children: E-scooter crash survivor calls for stronger regulations

image.altText: An external shot of a police station.

props.synopsis: Confidential Northern Territory police data shows there were nearly 20 cases of self-harm involving Indigenous teenagers in police station watch houses over a six-month period.

title.children: 'They shouldn't be in there': Children self-harming in NT custody

image.altText: Looking up at the pillars outside the Victorian Parliament.

props.synopsis: The Victorian government will move to make it even harder for repeat offenders to get bail when parliament resumes today, while the opposition and Greens will scrutinise scandals in the childcare sector.

title.children: Victorian government eyes further bail changes as its critics target childcare crisis

image.altText: Houses close to the shore with rocks in front of them on a small peninsula jutting into the ocean.

props.synopsis: Property owners in the SA town of Pelican Point may be sceptical of predictions their town will be under water in 75 years but they are tired of waiting for authorities to act.

title.children: Homeowners take battle with the sea into their own hands

image.altText: A stressed female worker looking overwhelmed with things shoved in her face like a phone, diary and watch

props.synopsis: When the pressure is on, it's easy to skip a break to focus on work. But not taking breaks can quickly become a dangerous habit.

title.children: Skipping a work break can cause us long-term harm

image.altText: Rupert Murdoch and Donald Trump

props.synopsis: Donald Trump is suing The Wall Street Journal, its owners, including Rupert Murdoch, and the reporters who wrote a story alleging the US president sent Jeffrey Epstein a letter on his birthday.

title.children: Trump asks for swift deposition of Murdoch in Epstein defamation case

image.altText: New Year's Eve fireworks over sydney harbour and the harbour bridge

props.synopsis: Viewing Sydney's multi-million-dollar fireworks show from North Sydney Council's prime vantage point on New Year's Eve will cost at least $50 — even though it is public land.

title.children: 'Heavy heart': Council to charge NYE revellers for fireworks vantage point

image.altText: Two women, one in indigenous head dress and cloak, smile at the camera.

props.synopsis: Traditional owners in Victoria's north-west are the first in the state to be granted exclusive native title rights. But what does that mean and how will it work?

title.children: Victoria has introduced the strongest form of native title. Here's how it works

image.altText: A woman talking in front of a crowd.

props.synopsis: Councillor Louise Elliot's motion to move Acknowledgements of Country and Welcomes to Country practices out of formal council proceedings fails.

title.children: Councillor's push to drop 'quasi-religious' Acknowledgement of Country defeated

image.altText: Heather Calgaret wears a possum cloak.

props.synopsis: Victorian Aboriginal communities are urging the state government to act on the recommendations of a coroner who investigated the 2021 death in custody of Heather Calgaret.

title.children: Victoria urged to act on coroner's death in custody recommendations

image.altText: Lorena Wiebes wins Tour de France Femmes stage.

props.synopsis: Lorena Wiebes prevails in a chaotic sprint to claim victory in the third stage of the Tour de France Femmes, with fellow Dutch rider Marianne Vos taking the overall lead.

title.children: Wiebes wins chaotic sprint in Tour de France Femmes stage three

image.altText: Five dark purple tomatoes. Four are whole, the front one has been cut in half displaying bright purple flesh and seeds

props.synopsis: Food companies are welcoming a proposal to exclude gene-edited products from the definition of genetically modified food, but organic producers say it takes away consumers' choice.

title.children: Fears change to genetically modified food labels will 'mislead' shoppers

image.altText: Donald Trump smiling as Ursula von der Leyen looks on with a serious expression.

props.synopsis: The European Union is defending the trade deal it has struck with the US, after a mixed reaction from the leaders of several major economies.

title.children: Trump has struck a trade deal with the EU. Why are so many European leaders unhappy?

image.altText: Three men in suits smile at the camera while shaking hands

props.synopsis: The two neighbouring Asian nations have agreed to an immediate and unconditional ceasefire after days of conflict, according to Malaysian Prime Minister Anwar Ibrahim.

title.children: Thailand and Cambodia ceasefire comes into effect

image.altText: The clasped feet of a ten-month-old baby boy on a blue rug.

props.synopsis: Beijing has announced a nationwide childcare subsidy policy to try and encourage people to have more children, but experts are not convinced the strategy will work.

title.children: China to give parents childcare cash in bid to lift declining birth rate

image.altText: A woman with short black hair speaks into microphones standing behind a lectern with red, white and blue flags behind her

props.synopsis: It had been hoped that South Korea's recent moves to scale back propaganda along the border might improve relations between the long-time enemies.

title.children: Kim Jong Un's sister rejects peace overtures from South Korea

image.altText: Adam Sandler taking a golf swing.

props.synopsis: It's been almost 30 years since Adam Sandler's Happy Gilmore changed golf forever. After watching the long anticipated sequel you may wish he stayed in retirement.

title.children: Happy Gilmore 2 is good business but a forgettable sequel

image.altText: Photos of a home with toys, soft furnishings.

props.synopsis: This Sydney mother and her two children fled a violent home with little more than the clothes on their backs. Now they have their very own sanctuary.

title.children: This mum and her kids left a refuge with nothing. Now they have a safe haven

image.altText: A close-up of a woman's face. She has brown hair in a pixie cut, a colourful scarf, a green knit and is smiling at the camera.

props.synopsis: The wait time for some cancer survivors to donate blood has been slashed from five years after their last treatment, to just one. The change comes a fortnight after restrictions on part of the LGBTQIA+ community were loosed.

title.children: Further changes to blood donation eligibility during record high demand

image.altText: Rainbow over cropping farm at Walpeup, Victoria.

props.synopsis: Welcome rain has brought smiles to farmers' faces and boosted water storages in Victoria.

title.children: Rain a 'lifesaver' for struggling farmers, but more is needed
